conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to use the properties of an ideal transformer and the relationships between the voltages and currents in the primary and secondary coils.
The voltage across \( R_3 \) is given as 10 V. Since \( R_1 = R_2 = R_3 = 50 \Omega \), the voltage across \( R_2 \) is also 10 V.
Using Ohm's law, the current through \( R_2 \) is \( I_{R2} = \frac{V_{R2}}{R_2} = \frac{10 \text{ V}}{50 \Omega} = 0.2 \text{ A} \).
The current through \( R_3 \) is \( I_{R3} = \frac{V_{R3}}{R_3} = \frac{10 \text{ V}}{50 \Omega} = 0.2 \text{ A} \).

The current through \( R_1 \) is the same as the current through \( R_2 \) and \( R_3 \) because they are in parallel, so \( I_{R1} = I_{R2} + I_{R3} = 0.2 \text{ A} + 0.2 \text{ A} = 0.4 \text{ A} \).

The voltage across the secondary coil is the sum of the voltages across \( R_1 \), \( R_2 \), and \( R_3 \). Therefore, the voltage across the secondary coil is \( V_{\text{secondary}} = V_{R1} + V_{R2} + V_{R3} = 0.4 \text{ A} \cdot 50 \Omega + 0.2 \text{ A} \cdot 50 \Omega + 0.2 \text{ A} \cdot 50 \Omega = 20 \text{ V} + 10 \text{ V} + 10 \text{ V} = 40 \text{ V} \).

The voltage across the primary coil is the product of the turns ratio and the voltage across the secondary coil. The turns ratio is given by the ratio of the number of turns in the primary to the number of turns in the secondary.

The power in the secondary coil is \( P_{\text{secondary}} = V_{\text{secondary}} \cdot I_{\text{secondary}} = 40 \text{ V} \cdot (0.4 \text{ A} + 0.2 \text{ A} + 0.2 \text{ A}) = 40 \text{ V} \cdot 0.8 \text{ A} = 32 \text{ W} \).

The power in the primary coil is \( P_{\text{primary}} = V_{\text{primary}} \cdot I_{\text{primary}} = V_{\text{primary}} \cdot 1.4 \text{ A} \). Since the power is conserved, \( P_{\text{primary}} = P_{\text{secondary}} \), so \( V_{\text{primary}} \cdot 1.4 \text{ A} = 32 \text{ W} \implies V_{\text{primary}} = \frac{32 \text{ W}}{1.4 \text{ A}} = \frac{32}{1.4} \text{ V} \approx 22.86 \text{ V} \).
